title: Alfred's Weekly Picks
description: A weekly curated selection of thought-provoking articles across technology, culture, and innovation.

items.title: The Forgotten Art of Soviet Bus Stops
items.content_html: An exploration of the surreal, sculptural bus stops built across the Soviet Union in the 1970s and 80s. These structures remain as artifacts of a unique design philosophy that prioritized public infrastructure as art.
items.summary: Surreal architectural artifacts from the Soviet era reveal how public infrastructure can be transformed into art.

_picks.selection_reason: This piece beautifully demonstrates how design choices reflect cultural values. The bus stops serve as a reminder that infrastructure doesn't have to be purely utilitarian — it can inspire and provoke thought.

items.title: Jimi Hendrix Was a Systems Engineer
items.content_html: Before revolutionizing rock music, Jimi Hendrix served as a paratrooper in the 101st Airborne. This article argues that his military training in systems thinking and improvisation directly influenced his approach to sound engineering and musical innovation.
items.summary: Hendrix's military background in systems thinking shaped his revolutionary approach to music and sound engineering.

_picks.selection_reason: A fascinating reframe that connects unexpected domains. It shows how skills from one field can catalyze breakthrough innovation in another — a lesson for anyone working at the intersection of disciplines.

items.title: The Coming Model Collapse: When AI Trains on AI
items.content_html: Researchers warn that as synthetic AI-generated content floods the internet, future AI models trained on this data may experience 'model collapse' — a degradation in quality and diversity. The article explores the implications for the future of machine learning.
items.summary: AI training on AI-generated content could lead to quality degradation and loss of diversity in future models.

_picks.selection_reason: A crucial warning about second-order effects in AI development. This isn't just theoretical — it has immediate implications for anyone building or using AI systems today.

items.title: Five Years of Rust in Production: Lessons from the Trenches
items.content_html: A battle-tested guide from engineering teams at Cloudflare, Discord, and AWS who have run Rust in production for years. They share hard-won lessons about when Rust shines, where it struggles, and how to build teams around it.
items.summary: Engineering teams share practical insights from running Rust in production at scale for five years.

_picks.selection_reason: Beyond the hype, this offers real-world engineering wisdom. The trade-offs and team dynamics insights are valuable even if you're not using Rust — they apply to any technology adoption decision.

items.title: The Quiet Revolution: Ambient Computing's Disappearing Interfaces
items.content_html: As voice assistants, smart homes, and wearables mature, we're entering an era where computing fades into the background. This piece examines how the best interfaces might be the ones we don't notice — and what that means for designers and users.
items.summary: The next computing paradigm is invisible: interfaces that fade into the background of daily life.

_picks.selection_reason: Captures an emerging trend that's already reshaping how we interact with technology. The shift from 'apps' to 'ambient presence' has profound implications for product design and user behavior.
